title: People's Judge Joseph Wapner dies aged 97 after pioneering courtroom reality TV
text:

Judge Joseph Wapner has died at the age of 97, after a career that saw him help pioneer court-based reality TV. 
The star - who hosted his own programme The People's Court for over a decade - had an audience of millions for his rulings over real life small claims cases. 
His son David Wapner confirmed his father passed away in his sleep in Los Angeles over the weekend, and it comes after he was hospitalised with breathing problems recently. Judge Wapner's show pioneered a genre He was recognised on the Walk of Fame in 2009 (Photo: Getty) 
Before making the move to television, Judge Wapner was on the beach of the LA Superior Court for 18 years. 
Many of the US Supreme Court's top judges were said to be fans of this show. His programme set the standard He passed away over the weekend (Photo: REUTERS) 
In one memorable moment, Wapner - who has received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame - settled a dispute on the Tonight Show between Johnny Carson and David Letterman. 
It came after Letterman's truck was towed away from a Malibu street on the request of Carson, who called it an eyesore. Wapner poses with the Hollywood High School cheer squad after being honoured with his star (Photo: Getty) 
However, the judge awarded the former $24.95 after the truck's headlights were damaged when returned to him. 
Although his TV audience declined early in the 1990s, there was a surge of popularity in 1997 following the launch of Judge Judy - although Wapner didn't watch the programme. Like us on Facebook
